chapter.title: Response accommodation allow for alternate ways to demonstrate skills
chapter.content:
In this topic, we will take a closer look at response accommodations, which allow an individual equal opportunity to demonstrate knowledge by using alternative forms of response that demonstrate their skills by avoiding means of expression affected by their learning disability. For many students this means accommodations that lessen their writing demands.

Alternative response accommodations include four general methods:

  1. alternative forms of response, which may include writing directly in a test booklet allows the student to forego the scanned "bubble" sheet;
  2. using scribes, or access assistants, who are trained to write only what the student dictates without editing;
  3. assistive technologies, such as voice recognition or speech-to-text software, word processing programs with spell check, abbreviation expanders, and outlining software programs; and
  4. other methods, such as graphic organizers and calculation devices.

State Resources to Help Students Access Assistive Technologies

 Many states have an Assistive Technology Financing Program, which can help individuals with disabilities get affordable loans to purchase assistive technologies such as hearing aids, vision aids, and adapted computers. State contacts for these programs as managed by RESNA, the Rehabilitation Engineering and Assistive Technology Society of North America. 

States may also offer Protection & Advocacy Programs to offer legal and advocacy services to assist individuals with disabilities in obtaining assistive technology devices and services from funding sources such as Medicare, Medicaid, private insurance companies, special education programs, an state vocational rehabilitation agencies.

chapter.title: Response accommodation resources
chapter.content:
Resources available to students needing response accommodations include text-to-speech software. Text-to-speech software allows students to use alternative means to provide responses where written communication may be difficult for those with learning disabilities. A variety of freeware and shareware, such as those listed below, are also available on the Internet to assist with text-to-speech. For more information on these free text-to speech software, click on the titles:  

  • Balabolka
  • Natural Reader
  • Panopretor
  • Wordtalk
  • Zabaware
  • Tucows
  • Additional Information

Click-N-Type, is a free on-screen virtual keyboard designed for an individual who may have a disability which prevents him or her from typing on a physical computer keyboard.  As long as the learner can control the mouse, he or she can type!

chapter.title: Does Jamilla qualify for accommodations?
chapter.content:
Read the next scenario to learn about Jamilla’s story, then determine whether she qualifies for accommodations. 

Jamilla

Jamilla, a thirty-eight-year-old student, is currently attending ABE classes at her local community college in order to obtain a GED. When she was an adolescent attending a low-performing high school, the expectations for success and the support services were lacking. Therefore, Jamilla dropped out of high school.

Based on the information provided, does Jamilla qualify for GED accommodations?

  1. Yes
  2. No

chapter.title: Recommended accommodations
chapter.content:
Appropriate reading accommodations for a learner like Jamilla may include extra time on classroom assignments and writing tests, word processing with spell check, and scribes or note takers during classroom instruction. In addition, she might also benefit from word prediction software. A psychological evaluation may be appropriate in this case.  


Jamilla

Jamilla, a thirty-eight-year-old student, is currently attending ABE classes at her local community college in order to obtain a GED. When she was an adolescent attending a low-performing high school, the expectations for success and the support services were lacking. Therefore, Jamilla dropped out of high school.

 

Underachievement in writing is a hallmark of many adolescents and adults with LD. Extra time or note-takers are appropriate accommodation for a writer such as Jamilla since she will require more time to recall the motor and orthographic patterns necessary to spell words. Research supports the effectiveness of spell checkers and word prediction programs for enhancing the writing performance of adolescents and adults with LD (Gregg, 2009).
